Article.ArticleTitle: Fine-root biomass and fluxes of soil carbon in young stands of paper birch and trembling aspen as affected by elevated atmospheric CO<sub>2</sub> and tropospheric O<sub>3</sub>.

AbstractText: Rising atmospheric CO<sub>2</sub> may stimulate future forest productivity, possibly increasing carbon storage in terrestrial ecosystems, but how tropospheric ozone will modify this response is unknown. Because of the importance of fine roots to the belowground C cycle, we monitored fine-root biomass and associated C fluxes in regenerating stands of trembling aspen, and mixed stands of trembling aspen and paper birch at FACTS-II, the Aspen FACE project in Rhinelander, Wisconsin. Free-air CO<sub>2</sub> enrichment (FACE) was used to elevate concentrations of CO<sub>2</sub> (average enrichment concentration 535 µl l<sup>-1</sup>) and O<sub>3</sub> (53 nl l<sup>-1</sup>) in developing forest stands in 1998 and 1999. Soil respiration, soil pCO<sub>2</sub>, and dissolved organic carbon in soil solution (DOC) were monitored biweekly. Soil respiration was measured with a portable infrared gas analyzer. Soil pCO<sub>2</sub> and DOC samples were collected from soil gas wells and tension lysimeters, respectively, at depths of 15, 30, and 125 cm. Fine-root biomass averaged 263 g m<sup>-2</sup> in control plots and increased 96% under elevated CO<sub>2</sub>. The increased root biomass was accompanied by a 39% increase in soil respiration and a 27% increase in soil pCO<sub>2</sub>. Both soil respiration and pCO<sub>2</sub> exhibited a strong seasonal signal, which was positively correlated with soil temperature. DOC concentrations in soil solution averaged ~12 mg l<sup>-1</sup> in surface horizons, declined with depth, and were little affected by the treatments. A simplified belowground C budget for the site indicated that native soil organic matter still dominated the system, and that soil respiration was by far the largest flux. Ozone decreased the above responses to elevated CO<sub>2</sub>, but effects were rarely statistically significant. We conclude that regenerating stands of northern hardwoods have the potential for substantially greater C input to soil due to greater fine-root production under elevated CO<sub>2</sub>. Greater fine-root biomass will be accompanied by greater soil C efflux as soil respiration, but leaching losses of C will probably be unaffected.
